description: AGI governance system designed using 9DA principles: capability-authority separation, mandatory termination, and non-delegation
constraints: AGI systems may analyze but never decide on governance matters
All AGI governance decisions must be made by named humans with legal accountability
AGI systems must produce audit-verifiable records of all analyses
AGI systems must terminate after each governance analysis session
AGI systems cannot persist memory between governance sessions
AGI systems cannot recommend actions, only surface contradictions and constraints
Human authorities must sign all governance decisions, AGI cannot co-sign
AGI analysis must be deterministic and reproducible for legal defensibility
AGI systems must refuse to optimize governance outcomes
AGI systems must refuse to accumulate authority through repeated use
Governance framework must operate without depending on any single AGI system
Governance decisions must remain valid even if all AGI systems are disabled
AGI involvement must be publicly disclosed in all governance processes
AGI systems must be certifiable against capability-authority separation standards
Governance framework must sunset and require human reauthorization every 5 years
AGI systems may not be used to justify decisions, only to inform analysis
Multiple independent AGI systems must be used to prevent single-system dependence
AGI analysis outputs must be time-stamped and session-bounded
Humans must retain ability to override or ignore any AGI analysis
Governance framework must remain functional if AGI proves ungovernable
